## Data-Driven Coaching

Analytics in Youth Coach Hub transforms your tagged film into actionable insights. Track team performance, identify trends over the season, and evaluate individual player development.

### What You'll Learn

- **[Team Analytics](/guide/analytics/team-analytics)** - Overall team performance metrics and play effectiveness
- **[Season Trends](/guide/analytics/season-trends)** - Track improvement and patterns across games
- **[Player Stats](/guide/analytics/player-stats)** - Individual player performance and development

### Prerequisites

To generate meaningful analytics, you need:

1. **Tagged Film** - Plays tagged with outcomes (yards, success, etc.)
2. **Roster Setup** - Players added to track individual stats
3. **Multiple Games** - More data = better insights

### Analytics Philosophy

Youth Coach Hub analytics focus on:

- **Success Rate** - Did the play achieve its goal?
- **Efficiency** - Yards per play, points per drive
- **Situational Performance** - How you perform in key situations
- **Development** - Are players and schemes improving?

### Quick Start

1. [Tag at least one game](/guide/film/tagging-plays) with play outcomes
2. Navigate to **Analytics** in your team dashboard
3. Explore team-wide metrics
4. Drill down into player-specific stats

## Overview

Player Stats provides individual performance metrics for every player on your roster. Track development over the season, compare players at the same position, and identify your top performers in key categories.

## Accessing Player Stats

### From Analytics

1. Navigate to **Analytics** in your team dashboard
2. Select the **Players** tab
3. View leaderboards and player rankings

### From Player Profile

1. Navigate to **Players** in your team dashboard
2. Click on a specific player
3. View their individual stat page

## Prerequisites

To generate player stats, you need:

1. **Roster Setup** - Players added with positions
2. **Tagged Film** - Plays tagged with player attribution
3. **Tagging Level** - Standard or Comprehensive tagging captures more player data

## Offensive Player Stats

### Quarterback Stats

| Stat | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Completions/Attempts** | Pass attempts and completions |
| **Completion %** | Percentage of passes completed |
| **Passing Yards** | Total yards through the air |

| **Touchdowns** | Passing touchdowns |
| **Interceptions** | Passes intercepted |

- Decision Grade - Quality of reads

- Create highlight reels with context

### Parent Communication

- Playing time information
- Performance highlights
- Development progress

## Filtering and Sorting

### By Position

View stats for specific positions:

- All quarterbacks
- All running backs
- All receivers
- Defensive positions

### By Game

Stats from specific games:

- Single game performance
- Home games only
- Conference games only

### By Situation

Filter to specific situations:

- Red zone plays only
- Third down plays only
- Close game situations

## Exporting Player Stats

### Individual Reports

Generate player-specific reports:

1. Open player profile
2. Click **Export** or **Print**
3. Choose format and stats to include

### Team Stat Sheets

Create team-wide stat sheets:

- Season stat summary
- Leaderboard printouts
- Position group reports

### Share Options

Stats can be:

- Printed for players
- Shared with parents
- Included in coach reports

## Best Practices

### Accurate Attribution

For reliable stats:

- Attribute plays to correct players
- Verify jersey numbers
- Double-check unusual stats

### Context Matters

Remember stats don't tell everything:

- Opponent quality
- Blocking/coverage help
- Scheme responsibilities
- Role within the team

### Consistent Tracking

For meaningful comparisons:

- Tag every game
- Use same tagging depth
- Attribute all players involved

### Celebrate Improvement

Focus on development:

- Personal bests
- Improvement trends
- Effort indicators

## Troubleshooting

### Stats Not Showing

If player stats are missing:

- Verify player is on roster
- Check that plays are attributed to them
- Ensure correct tagging level used

### Incorrect Stats

If numbers seem wrong:

- Review tagged plays
- Check for duplicate entries
- Verify player attribution

### Missing Players

If players aren't appearing:

- Add them to the roster
- Tag new plays with their attribution
- Check position filters

## Next Steps

- [View team analytics](/guide/analytics/team-analytics) for overall performance
- [Check season trends](/guide/analytics/season-trends) for improvement patterns
- [Tag plays](/guide/film/tagging-plays) to capture more player data

analytics/season-trends.content:
## Overview

Season Trends helps you see the big picture of your team's development. Track how performance evolves game-by-game, identify improvement areas, and spot patterns that single-game analytics might miss.

## Accessing Season Trends

1. Navigate to your team dashboard
2. Click **Analytics** in the team navigation
3. Select the **Trends** or **Season** tab

## Why Trends Matter

Single-game analytics can be misleading:

- Small sample sizes
- Opponent quality varies
- Game circumstances differ

Season trends smooth out the noise and reveal:

- Actual improvement or regression
- Consistent strengths and weaknesses
- Patterns in performance

## Key Trend Charts

### Success Rate Over Time

A line chart showing success rate game-by-game:

- **Upward trend** - Team is improving
- **Flat line** - Consistent performance
- **Downward trend** - Regression to address
- **Moving average** - Smoothed trend line

### Yards Per Play Trend

Track efficiency over the season:

- Compare early season to late season
- Identify breakout games
- Spot concerning dips

### Points Per Game

Offensive and defensive scoring trends:

- Points scored per game
- Points allowed per game
- Point differential trend

## Offensive Trends

### Run Game Development

Track rushing performance evolution:

| Metric | Weeks 1-4 | Weeks 5-8 | Change |
|--------|-----------|-----------|--------|
| Rush Success % | 45% | 58% | +13% |
| Yards/Carry | 3.8 | 4.6 | +0.8 |
| Explosive Runs | 2/game | 4/game | +2 |

### Pass Game Development

Track passing performance over time:

- Completion percentage trend
- Yards per attempt trend
- Explosive pass rate

### Red Zone Improvement

Are you finishing drives better as the season progresses?

- TD rate by month
- Points per red zone trip
- Red zone play selection changes

### Third Down Conversion

Critical situation improvement:

- 3rd & Short conversion trend
- 3rd & Long conversion trend
- Overall 3rd down percentage

## Defensive Trends

### Points Allowed Trend

Track defensive improvement:

- Points per game allowed
- Points per drive allowed
- Scoring defense trend

### Stop Rate Development

Are you getting better at forcing punts?

- 3-and-out rate over time
- Opponent success rate trend
- Turnover creation trend

### Situational Defense

How has your situational defense evolved?

- 3rd down stop rate trend
- Red zone defense trend
- Big play prevention

## Comparing Time Periods

### First Half vs. Second Half

Compare early and late season:

| Category | First Half | Second Half |
|----------|------------|-------------|
| Wins | 2 | 5 |
| PPG | 18.5 | 28.2 |
| Success Rate | 48% | 57% |
| YPP | 4.6 | 5.8 |

### Pre-Bye vs. Post-Bye

If your schedule includes a bye week:

- Performance before rest
- Performance after rest
- Identify bye week impact

### Monthly Breakdown

See development by month:

- August/September (early)
- October (mid-season)
- November (late season)
- Playoffs (if applicable)

## Identifying Patterns

### Game Script Patterns

Do you perform differently based on game flow?

- Performance when ahead
- Performance when behind
- Close game execution

### Home vs. Away

Track location-based trends:

- Home game success rate
- Away game success rate
- Consistent or different?

### Weather Impact

If you track conditions:

- Performance in good weather
- Performance in rain/cold
- Adjustments needed?

### Opponent Type Patterns

Performance against different opponents:

- Vs. winning teams trend
- Vs. similar-level opponents
- Vs. conference rivals

## Scheme Development

### Formation Trends

Are you shifting your approach?

- Early season formation usage
- Late season formation usage
- Success rate changes by formation

### Personnel Trends

Track personnel package evolution:

- Which groupings are you using more?
- Which have improved?
- Which have you moved away from?

### Concept Efficiency

How are your core concepts developing?

| Concept | Early Season | Late Season | Trend |
|---------|--------------|-------------|-------|
| Inside Zone | 48% | 62% | ↑ |
| Power | 55% | 58% | → |
| Mesh | 52% | 65% | ↑ |
| Four Verts | 40% | 45% | → |

## Player Development Trends

### Key Players

Track your important players over time:

- QB improvement curve
- RB efficiency trend
- Top receiver development

### Position Group Trends

See which position groups are improving:

- Offensive line run blocking trend
- Defensive back coverage trend
- Linebacker tackling trend

## Using Trends for Decisions

### Doubling Down on Strengths

If something is trending up:

- Use it more
- Build around it
- Develop variations

### Addressing Declining Areas

If something is trending down:

- Identify the cause
- Make scheme adjustments
- Consider personnel changes

### Playoff Preparation

Use trends to peak at the right time:

- What's working now?
- What's improved most?
- What do we do best?

## Visualizations

### Trend Lines

- Solid line: Actual performance
- Dotted line: Moving average
- Shaded area: Range of performance

### Comparison Charts

- Side-by-side bar charts
- Before/after visualizations
- Improvement indicators

### Season Timeline

- Key games marked
- Performance peaks and valleys
- Important dates noted

## Exporting Trend Data

### Season Reports

Generate end-of-season summaries:

- Overall record and stats
- Key trend highlights
- Year-over-year comparison (if available)

### Staff Presentations

Create visuals for:

- Team meetings
- Parent presentations
- End-of-season reviews

## Best Practices

### Consistent Tagging

Trends require consistent data:

- Tag every game
- Use same tagging depth
- Don't skip games

### Regular Review

Check trends throughout the season:

- Weekly: Quick trend check
- Monthly: Deeper trend analysis
- End of season: Full review

### Context Matters

Consider factors beyond the numbers:

- Opponent quality
- Weather conditions
- Injury impact
- Practice time available

### Multi-Year Tracking

If you keep historical data:

- Compare to last season
- Track program development
- Identify long-term patterns

## Troubleshooting

### Not Enough Data

Trends need multiple games:

- Minimum 3-4 games for meaningful trends
- More games = more reliable trends
- Be patient early in season

### Inconsistent Trends

If data seems unreliable:

- Check tagging consistency
- Verify play count accuracy
- Consider opponent context

### Missing Visualizations

If charts aren't appearing:

- Ensure games are tagged
- Check date range filter
- Verify data exists for the period

## Next Steps

- [View team analytics](/guide/analytics/team-analytics) for current metrics
- [Check player stats](/guide/analytics/player-stats) for individual trends
- [Tag more games](/guide/film/tagging-plays) to build trend data

## Overview

Team Analytics provides a high-level view of your team's performance across all tagged games. Use these insights to evaluate your scheme, identify strengths and weaknesses, and make informed game planning decisions.

## Accessing Team Analytics

1. Navigate to your team dashboard
2. Click **Analytics** in the team navigation
3. Select the **Team** tab (default view)

## Key Metrics

### Success Rate

The percentage of plays that achieved their situational goal:

| Down | Success Threshold |
|------|-------------------|
| **1st Down** | Gain 40% of distance needed (e.g., 4+ yards on 1st & 10) |
| **2nd Down** | Gain 60% of remaining distance |
| **3rd/4th Down** | Convert for first down or score |

**Why It Matters:** Success rate is a better predictor of offensive efficiency than yards per play because it accounts for situational context.

### Yards Per Play (YPP)

Average yards gained per offensive snap:

- **Elite:** 6.0+ YPP
- **Good:** 5.0-5.9 YPP
- **Average:** 4.0-4.9 YPP
- **Below Average:** Under 4.0 YPP

### Explosive Play Rate

Percentage of plays that gain significant yardage:

- **Explosive Run:** 10+ yards
- **Explosive Pass:** 15+ yards

High explosive rates often correlate with scoring success.

### Points Per Drive

Average points scored per offensive possession:

- Includes touchdowns (6-7 pts), field goals (3 pts), and failed drives (0 pts)
- Better indicator than total points because it's adjusted for opportunities

## Offensive Analytics

### Run vs. Pass Breakdown

See your run/pass ratio and effectiveness:

| Metric | Run | Pass |
|--------|-----|------|
| Attempts | Count | Count |
| Success Rate | % | % |
| Yards Per Play | Avg | Avg |
| Explosive Plays | Count | Count |

### By Formation

Analyze performance by formation:

- Success rate per formation
- Average yards per formation
- Play count by formation
- Identify your most effective looks

### By Personnel Grouping

Compare personnel package effectiveness:

| Personnel | Plays | Success % | YPP |
|-----------|-------|-----------|-----|
| 11 (3WR) | 45 | 52% | 5.8 |
| 12 (2TE) | 28 | 61% | 4.2 |
| 21 (2RB) | 15 | 47% | 3.9 |

### By Play Concept

Track which concepts work best:

- Inside Zone: 55% success, 4.8 YPP
- Outside Zone: 48% success, 5.2 YPP
- Power: 62% success, 4.1 YPP
- Mesh Concept: 58% success, 7.2 YPP

### Red Zone Efficiency

Performance inside the opponent's 20-yard line:

- **TD Rate** - Touchdowns per red zone trip
- **Points Per Trip** - Average points scored
- **Play Selection** - Run/pass ratio in red zone

## Defensive Analytics

### Points Allowed Per Drive

Average points surrendered per defensive possession:

- Lower is better
- Accounts for defensive opportunities

### Opponent Success Rate

How often opponents achieve their situational goals against your defense.

### Stops and Havoc

- **3-and-Out Rate** - Forcing punts after 3 plays
- **TFL Rate** - Tackles for loss percentage
- **Turnover Rate** - Forced turnovers per game
- **Havoc Rate** - Disruptive plays (TFL + FF + INT + PBU) / snaps

### By Down

See defensive performance by situation:

| Down | Opp Success % | Avg Yards Allowed |
|------|---------------|-------------------|
| 1st | 45% | 4.2 |
| 2nd | 38% | 3.8 |
| 3rd | 28% | 4.5 |

### By Formation Faced

Track how you defend different looks:

- Performance vs. Spread formations
- Performance vs. Under Center
- Performance vs. Heavy sets

## Situational Analytics

### Down and Distance

Performance broken down by situation:

**1st Down:**
- Success rate
- Average gain
- Run/pass split

**2nd & Short (1-3 yards):**
- Conversion rate
- Play selection

**2nd & Long (7+ yards):**
- Success rate
- Passing efficiency

**3rd Down:**
- Conversion rate by distance
- Play selection tendencies

### Field Position

Performance by area of the field:

| Zone | Success % | Avg Gain |
|------|-----------|----------|
| Own 1-20 | 48% | 4.2 |
| Own 21-50 | 55% | 5.1 |
| Opp 21-50 | 52% | 5.4 |
| Red Zone | 58% | 3.8 |

### Game Situation

Performance by score differential:

- **Ahead by 7+** - Protect lead situations
- **Within 7** - Close game performance
- **Behind by 7+** - Comeback situations

### Quarter Breakdown

See how you perform by game phase:

- 1st Quarter - Starting performance
- 2nd Quarter - Pre-half execution
- 3rd Quarter - Halftime adjustments
- 4th Quarter - Closing ability

## Filtering Data

### By Game

Select specific games to analyze:

- Single game deep dive
- Compare home vs. away
- Regular season vs. playoffs

### By Date Range

Analyze specific time periods:

- First half of season
- Last 3 games
- Post-bye week

### By Opponent Type

If you track opponent quality:

- Performance vs. winning teams
- Performance vs. similar opponents

## Charts and Visualizations

### Success Rate Chart

Line graph showing success rate trend over the season.

### Play Distribution

Pie chart showing run/pass/RPO breakdown.

### Down Efficiency

Bar chart comparing conversion rates by down.

### Formation Heatmap

Visual showing which formations you use most and their success rates.

## Exporting Analytics

### Print Reports

Generate printable analytics summaries:

1. Click **Export** or **Print**
2. Select metrics to include
3. Choose format (PDF, print)

### Share with Staff

Analytics pages can be:

- Viewed by all coaches on the team
- Screenshotted for presentations
- Discussed in staff meetings

## Using Analytics for Game Planning

### Identify Strengths

Find what works and do more of it:

- High success formations
- Effective play concepts
- Best situational plays

### Address Weaknesses

Spot areas needing improvement:

- Low success situations
- Ineffective concepts
- Problem down-and-distances

### Game-Specific Preparation

Use analytics to prepare for opponents:

- What works against similar defenses?
- Where do we struggle?
- What adjustments are needed?

## Best Practices

### Tag Consistently

Analytics are only as good as your tagging:

- Tag all plays, not just big ones
- Include accurate yardage
- Mark situational details

### Review Weekly

Make analytics part of your routine:

- Post-game: Quick review
- Mid-week: Deep dive for game plan
- End of season: Full evaluation

### Compare Over Time

Track improvement:

- This week vs. last week
- This year vs. last year
- First half vs. second half

## Next Steps

- [Track season trends](/guide/analytics/season-trends) over multiple games
- [View player stats](/guide/analytics/player-stats) for individual performance
- [Tag more plays](/guide/film/tagging-plays) to improve data quality

film/tagging-plays.content:
## Overview

Play tagging is the process of marking individual plays in your game film with detailed information. This data powers all of Youth Coach Hub's analytics features.

## Getting Started

### Open the Film Viewer

1. Navigate to your team's **Film** section
2. Select a game
3. Click on a video to open the film viewer

### Basic Tagging Workflow

1. **Play the video** until you reach the start of a play
2. Click **Mark Start** to set the play's beginning
3. Let the play run, then click **Mark End**
4. Fill in the play details in the tagging form
5. Click **Save Play** to record the tag

## Understanding Tagging Levels

Youth Coach Hub offers different levels of detail based on your needs:

### Quick

*Track the game, remember the season* (~15-20 sec per play)

Capture game essentials without the time investment:

- Quarter and time
- Ball carrier
- Yards gained
- Result (touchdown, first down, etc.)
- Turnovers and big plays

### Standard

*Understand what's working, prepare for next week* (~30-45 sec per play)

Add play-level context to see which plays succeed:

- All Quick fields
- Down and distance
- Formation and play type
- QB and target (for passes)
- Drive tracking
- Situational tendencies

### Comprehensive

*Evaluate and develop every player* (~2-3 min per play)

Full player-level tracking for detailed analysis:

- All Standard fields
- Position-by-position grades for all offensive players
- Position-by-position grades for all defensive players
- Situational tags (motion, blitz, etc.)
- Coverage information

## Play Details

### Context Fields

| Field | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| Down | 1st, 2nd, 3rd, or 4th down |
| Distance | Yards needed for first down |
| Yard Line | Field position (1-99) |
| Hash | Left, middle, or right hash |

### Result Fields

| Field | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| Yards Gained | Net yards on the play |
| Result | Outcome (complete, incomplete, run, etc.) |
| First Down | Did the play result in a first down? |
| Turnover | Was there a fumble or interception? |

## Auto-Population

Youth Coach Hub automatically calculates the next play's context based on the previous play:

- **Down** advances automatically
- **Distance** adjusts based on yards gained and penalties
- **Yard Line** updates based on the result

Auto-populated fields are highlighted in blue. You can always override these values manually.

> **Tip:** If a penalty was declined, check the "Penalty Declined" box so it doesn't affect the next play's calculations.

## Tagging Tips

### Be Consistent

Use the same criteria for success/failure across all plays. This ensures your analytics are meaningful.

### Tag Both Teams

Tag both your offensive plays and opponent's plays. This gives you:

- Defensive analytics for your team
- Scouting data on opponents

### Use Drives

Group plays into drives to see:

- Points per drive
- Drive efficiency
- Red zone performance

### Review Your Tags

Periodically review tagged plays to ensure accuracy. Incorrect tags lead to incorrect analytics.

## Keyboard Shortcuts

Speed up tagging with these shortcuts:

| Key | Action |
|-----|--------|
| `Space` | Play/Pause video |
| `[` | Mark play start |
| `]` | Mark play end |
| `Enter` | Save play |
| `Left Arrow` | Rewind 5 seconds |
| `Right Arrow` | Forward 5 seconds |

## Overview

Youth Coach Hub's film system allows you to upload game footage, tag individual plays, and generate analytics. This guide covers how to get your video into the platform.

## Supported Formats

The platform supports most common video formats:

- MP4 (recommended)
- MOV
- AVI
- WebM

> **Tip:** MP4 files typically provide the best balance of quality and file size for web playback.

## Uploading Video

### 1. Create a Game Record

Before uploading film, you need a game to associate it with:

1. Go to your team's **Schedule** tab
2. Click **Add Game**
3. Enter the game details (opponent, date, location)
4. Save the game

### 2. Upload the Video

1. Navigate to the game you just created
2. Click **Upload Film** or drag and drop your video file
3. Wait for the upload to complete (this may take a few minutes for longer videos)

### 3. Video Processing

After upload, the video will be processed for web playback. You'll see a progress indicator. Once complete, you can:

- Play the video in the built-in player
- Start tagging plays
- Add notes and markers

## Organizing Your Film Library

### Multiple Videos Per Game

You can upload multiple videos for a single game. This is useful when you have:

- First half and second half as separate files
- Different camera angles
- Sideline and end zone footage

### Naming Conventions

Use clear, consistent names for your videos:

- `vs-Eastside-Week3-Full.mp4`
- `vs-Eastside-Week3-Offense.mp4`
- `vs-Eastside-Week3-Defense.mp4`

## Storage Limits

Storage limits depend on your subscription plan:

| Plan | Storage |
|------|---------|
| Free | 5 GB |
| Pro | 50 GB |
| Team | 200 GB |

> **Note:** Older games can be archived to free up storage while preserving your play-by-play data and analytics.

## Troubleshooting

### Upload Stuck or Failed

1. Check your internet connection
2. Try a smaller file (compress if needed)
3. Ensure the video format is supported
4. Clear your browser cache and try again

### Video Won't Play

1. Wait for processing to complete
2. Try refreshing the page
3. Check if the video plays in another application (file may be corrupted)

## The Prepared Coach

When kickoff arrives, you've done the work. Game Day Ready is about having all your preparation organized and accessible so you can focus on coaching, not scrambling for information.

## Pre-Game Checklist

### Know Your Team

Before the game, review your own tendencies:

- **What's working** - Your highest success rate plays and formations
- **Situational strengths** - Where you execute best
- **Player matchups** - Who's performing well, who needs support
- **Key plays** - Your go-to calls for critical situations

### Know Your Opponent

Have these answers ready:

- **Their base defense/offense** - What will you see most often?
- **Tendency triggers** - What tips their hand? (Formation, personnel, alignment)
- **Blitz/pressure patterns** - When do they attack?
- **Exploitable weaknesses** - Where can you attack?

### Have Your Adjustments Ready

Pre-plan your responses:

| If They Show... | We Will... |
|----------------|-----------|
| Heavy man coverage | Run quick game, use motion |
| Soft zone | Attack intermediate zones |
| Overloaded box | Spread them out, use screens |
| Pressure | Hot routes, quick passes |

## Building Your Game Day Call Sheet

The call sheet is your organized menu of plays selected specifically for this game. Youth Coach Hub helps you build it based on data.

### Selecting Plays by Situation

From your playbook, select plays for each situation based on:

- **Success rate** from your analytics
- **Matchup** against opponent tendencies
- **Practice performance** during the week

### Call Sheet Structure

Organize your plays by situation:

| Situation | Plays Selected | Why |
|-----------|---------------|-----|
| **1st & 10** | Inside Zone, Outside Zone, PA Boot, Curl-Flat | High success rate on early downs |
| **2nd & Medium** | Counter, Slant-Flat, Draw, Screen | Balanced options |
| **2nd & Long** | Deep Cross, 4 Verts, Swing Pass | Need chunk plays |
| **3rd & Short** | Power, QB Sneak, Slant | Reliable converters |
| **3rd & Medium** | Mesh, Levels, Stick | 65%+ success rate |
| **3rd & Long** | Flood, 4 Verts, Screen | Best shot plays |
| **Red Zone** | Sprint Out, Fade, Power, PA Rollout | Scoring plays |
| **Goal Line** | QB Sneak, Dive, Bootleg, Fade | Short yardage |
| **2-Minute** | Quick outs, Spike, Sideline routes | Clock management |

### Generating the Call Sheet

1. Go to **Game Week > Call Sheet Builder**
2. Select the upcoming game
3. For each situation, choose plays from your playbook
4. The system shows success rates to inform your choices
5. Export or print your organized call sheet

## QB Wristband Printout

The wristband is the QB's quick reference on the field - a condensed version of the call sheet that fits on their arm.

### What Goes on the Wristband

Keep it simple and scannable:

```
┌─────────────────────────────┐
│     GAME DAY WRISTBAND      │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ 1ST DOWN                    │
│ 11-IZ  12-OZ  13-PA  14-CF  │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ 2ND MED                     │
│ 21-CTR 22-SL  23-DRW 24-SCR │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ 3RD SHORT                   │
│ 31-PWR 32-SNK 33-SLT        │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ 3RD MEDIUM                  │
│ 41-MSH 42-LVL 43-STK        │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ RED ZONE                    │
│ 51-SPO 52-FD  53-PWR 54-PA  │
├─────────────────────────────┤
│ GOAL LINE                   │
│ 61-SNK 62-DIV 63-BT  64-FD  │
└─────────────────────────────┘
```

### Creating the Wristband

1. Go to **Game Week > Wristband Builder**
2. Your call sheet plays auto-populate
3. Assign short codes (2-3 characters) to each play
4. Organize by situation category
5. Print to wristband-sized format

### Wristband Best Practices

- **Use consistent codes** - Same abbreviations every game
- **Limit choices** - 3-5 plays per situation max
- **Number system** - First digit = situation, second = play option
- **Practice with it** - QB should use wristband in practice

## Coach's Sideline Sheet

A larger format for the play-caller with more detail:

```
OPPONENT TENDENCIES
- 1st Down: 60% run, favor inside zone
- 3rd & Medium: 70% Cover 3, 30% blitz
- Red Zone: Heavy sets, power run

CALL SHEET BY SITUATION
[Full play names with formation and motion calls]

ADJUSTMENTS
- vs Cover 3: Attack seams, use out routes
- vs Man: Motion to create picks, quick game
- vs Pressure: Slide protection, hot routes

KEY REMINDERS
- Their #24 is their best cover corner
- They substitute on 3rd down - watch for nickel
- QB likes to scramble right under pressure
```

### Printing Options

Export your preparation materials:

- **Full Call Sheet** - Letter size, detailed
- **QB Wristband** - Wristband card format
- **Sideline Reference** - Laminated coaching sheet
- **Adjustment Card** - Quick if/then reference

## In-Game Adjustments

### First Quarter Observations

Use the first quarter to validate your preparation:

- Are they doing what you expected?
- What's different from the film?
- What adjustments do you need to make?

### Halftime Analysis

At halftime, quickly review:

- What's working? Do more of it.
- What's not working? Adjust or abandon.
- What are they doing differently? Counter it.

### Second Half Execution

Apply your adjustments:

- Call plays that attack what you're seeing
- Avoid plays that aren't working
- Trust your preparation

## Post-Game: Complete the Cycle

After the game, the cycle continues:

### Immediate Notes

While it's fresh, note:

- What adjustments worked?
- What didn't go as planned?
- What do you need to practice?

### Film Review Priorities

When you review film:

- Tag the game for your analytics
- Identify coaching points for players
- Note opponent tendencies for future reference

### Update Your Data

Your post-game film tagging:

- Updates your team's analytics
- Adds to your play-by-play history
- Improves future game preparation

## The Confidence of Preparation

When you walk onto the field:

- You've studied your opponent thoroughly
- You know your team's strengths and weaknesses
- You have data-backed play calls for every situation
- You've practiced against realistic looks
- You have adjustments ready for what they'll show

This is the competitive advantage of preparation. You're not guessing - you're making informed decisions based on evidence.

> **The Final Word:** Game Day Ready isn't about having all the answers. It's about having done the work so you can trust your decisions and coach your players with confidence. That's what Youth Coach Hub helps you achieve.

Armed with data, you can make informed decisions:

- Select plays that match up well against their defense
- Identify key adjustments based on what you expect to see
- Prepare answers for their most common looks
- Focus practice time on situational execution

## Data-Driven Practice

Practice time is limited. Youth Coach Hub helps you use it wisely by identifying exactly what your team needs to work on based on real performance data.

## Identifying Practice Priorities

### What to Work On

Your analytics reveal areas that need attention:

**Offensive Priorities:**
- Plays with low success rates that you want to keep calling
- Situations where you struggle (3rd down, red zone, goal line)
- Formations where your execution is inconsistent

**Defensive Priorities:**
- Coverages that opponents are attacking successfully
- Situations where you're giving up big plays
- Alignment or assignment issues showing up in film

### What's Working

Don't forget to reinforce success:

- High-success plays that deserve more reps
- Formations where your team executes consistently
- Situations where you're performing well

## Building Practice Scripts

### Offensive Scripts

Create practice scripts based on:

1. **Tendency Data** - What does the opponent usually show?
2. **Your Best Plays** - What should you call against those looks?
3. **Situation Focus** - What game situations need work?

**Example Script Building:**

| Situation | Opponent Tendency | Your Play Call |
|-----------|-------------------|----------------|
| 1st & 10 | Base 4-3, Cover 2 | Inside Zone, Play Action |
| 3rd & 5-7 | Nickel, Cover 3 | Slant-Flat, Mesh |
| Red Zone | Goal Line, Man | Sprint Out, Fade |

### Defensive Scripts

For your scout team offense:

1. Review opponent's most common plays
2. Build a card system based on their tendencies
3. Have scout team run realistic looks

## Practice Period Structure

### Individual Periods

Focus on technique work informed by film review:

- Position-specific corrections from game film
- Skill development for weaknesses identified in analytics
- Repetition of fundamentals that lead to success

### Team Periods

Structure team reps around game-like situations:

**Situational Practice Ideas:**

| Period | Focus | Data Source |
|--------|-------|-------------|
| 3rd Down | Converting/Stopping | 3rd down success rates |
| Red Zone | Scoring/Defending | Red zone efficiency |
| 2-Minute | Clock management | Drive analytics |
| Goal Line | Short yardage | Goal-to-go conversion |

### Scrimmage Periods

Create game-realistic scenarios:

- Start at specific down/distance/field position
- Use opponent tendencies for defensive looks
- Track success just like a game

## Tracking Practice to Game Correlation

Over time, you can see if practice is translating:

- Are plays you rep heavily performing better?
- Are situations you focus on improving?
- Is there carryover from practice to games?

## Weekly Practice Template

**Monday: Install & Corrections**
- Review film from previous game
- Identify areas for improvement
- Begin installing game plan

**Tuesday: Situational Focus**
- Practice identified priorities
- Run opponent scout looks
- Work on corrections from Monday

**Wednesday: Team Execution**
- Full team periods with game situations
- Polish game plan plays
- Simulate opponent tendencies

**Thursday: Fine-Tuning**
- Light practice
- Review key adjustments
- Walk through game plan

**Friday: Mental Prep**
- Walk through only
- Review scouting report
- Visualize game situations

> **Remember:** The goal isn't to practice everything - it's to practice the right things. Your analytics tell you what matters most.

## Understanding Your Opponent

Scouting reports transform tagged opponent film into actionable intelligence. Every play you've tagged about your opponent contributes to a clearer picture of what you'll face on game day.

## Generating a Scouting Report

### Prerequisites

To generate a meaningful scouting report, you need:

- At least one game with opponent plays tagged
- Basic tagging data (formation, play type, result)
- Ideally 20+ plays for statistical significance

### Creating the Report

1. Navigate to **Game Week** from your team dashboard
2. Select **Scouting Reports**
3. Choose the opponent you're preparing for
4. Select which games to include in the analysis
5. Click **Generate Report**

## What the Report Shows

### Defensive Tendencies

If you're scouting their defense:

| Metric | What It Tells You |
|--------|-------------------|
| Base Formation % | What defense do they line up in most? |
| Coverage Distribution | Man vs Zone breakdown |
| Blitz Rate by Down | When do they bring pressure? |
| Tendencies by Hash | Do they favor certain looks by field position? |

### Offensive Tendencies

If you're scouting their offense:

| Metric | What It Tells You |
|--------|-------------------|
| Run/Pass Ratio | Are they run-heavy or pass-happy? |
| Personnel Groupings | What formations do they favor? |
| Play Type by Down | What do they call on 1st down vs 3rd? |
| Key Players | Who gets the ball most often? |

### Situational Analysis

The report breaks down tendencies by situation:

- **Early Downs** (1st & 2nd) - What's their approach when ahead of schedule?
- **Third Down** - How do they convert? What do they call?
- **Red Zone** - How do they try to score?
- **Goal Line** - What's their go-to play?
- **Two-Minute** - How do they operate under time pressure?

## Using the Data

### Identify Exploitable Patterns

Look for:

- **Predictable tendencies** - Do they always run on 1st down?
- **Coverage tells** - Does their safety alignment give away the coverage?
- **Personnel-based patterns** - Do certain players only come in for certain plays?

### Prepare Counter-Strategies

For each tendency you identify:

1. Note the pattern
2. Select plays from your playbook that attack it
3. Practice recognition and execution

### Create Game Day Notes

Export key insights to a condensed format you can reference during the game:

- Top 5 things to remember
- Adjustments by situation
- Key players to watch

## Building Better Reports Over Time

The more opponent film you tag, the better your scouting reports become:

- **Multiple games** reveal consistent tendencies vs. one-game anomalies
- **Detailed tagging** (Standard or Comprehensive) provides richer analysis
- **Personnel tracking** shows substitution patterns

> **Pro Tip:** Tag opponent film immediately after games while it's fresh. The data you collect throughout the season makes your playoff scouting reports invaluable.

## Overview

Creating an account is your first step to accessing Youth Coach Hub's coaching tools. The process takes just a few minutes and you'll be ready to set up your team.

## Sign Up Options

There are two ways to create an account:

### 1. New Team Owner

If you're starting a new team or organization:

1. Visit the **Pricing** page and select a plan
2. Click **Get Started** to begin the signup process
3. You'll create your account and then set up your first team

### 2. Invited by Another Coach

If you've received an invitation to join an existing team:

1. Click the invitation link in your email
2. Create your account using the signup form
3. You'll automatically be added to the team that invited you

## Step-by-Step Account Creation

### 1. Enter Your Information

Fill in the signup form with:

| Field | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| Full Name | Your name as you want it displayed to other coaches |
| Email | Your email address (used for login and notifications) |
| Password | At least 8 characters |
| Confirm Password | Re-enter your password to verify |

### 2. Accept Terms of Service

Review and accept the terms of service by checking the checkbox at the bottom of the form.

### 3. Verify Your Email

After submitting the form:

1. Check your email inbox for a confirmation message
2. Click the **Confirm Email** link in the message
3. You'll be redirected to complete your setup

> **Note:** If you don't see the email, check your spam folder. The email comes from Youth Coach Hub.

## After Creating Your Account

Once your account is verified, you'll be directed to:

- **Team Setup** - If you're creating a new team
- **Your Team Dashboard** - If you joined via an invitation

## Troubleshooting

### Didn't receive the confirmation email?

- Check your spam/junk folder
- Make sure you entered the correct email address
- Try signing up again if needed

### Email already in use?

If you see this error, you may already have an account. Try:

1. Using the **Forgot Password** link to reset your password
2. Signing in with the existing account

### Password requirements

Your password must:

- Be at least 8 characters long
- We recommend using a mix of letters, numbers, and symbols

## Next Steps

After creating your account:

1. [Create your first team](/guide/getting-started/creating-first-team)
2. Add your roster
3. Upload game film
4. Start tagging plays

## Overview

Creating a team is the first step to unlocking all of Youth Coach Hub's features. Once your team is set up, you can add players, invite coaches, build your playbook, upload game film, and track analytics.

## Before You Begin

Make sure you have:

1. Created your Youth Coach Hub account ([see Creating Your Account](/guide/getting-started/creating-account))
2. Selected a subscription plan (Basic, Plus, or Premium)

## Step-by-Step Guide

### 1. Navigate to Team Setup

After signing up, you'll be automatically directed to the team setup page. If you're already logged in, you can access it by:

- Clicking **Setup** from the main menu
- Or clicking **Create New Team** from your dashboard

### 2. Select Your Plan

If you haven't already selected a plan, you'll see three options:

| Plan | Best For | Key Features |
|------|----------|--------------|
| **Basic** | Getting started | 2 uploads/month, 1 camera, 30-day storage |
| **Plus** | Serious coaches | 4 uploads/month, 3 cameras, 90-day storage |
| **Premium** | Complete toolkit | 8 uploads/month, 5 cameras, 1-year storage |

Click on the plan that fits your needs.

### 3. Enter Team Details

Fill in the following information:

| Field | Description | Example |
|-------|-------------|---------|
| **Team Name** | Your team's official name | "Westside Tigers" |
| **Level** | Select the appropriate level | Little League, Middle School, JV, Varsity |

### 4. Complete Checkout (Paid Plans)

For Plus and Premium plans:

1. Click **Continue to Checkout**
2. Enter your payment information in the secure Stripe checkout
3. Complete the purchase

For the Basic plan, you can start immediately without payment.

### 5. Access Your Team Dashboard

After creating your team, you'll be redirected to your team dashboard where you can:

- View your team's home page
- Access the playbook
- Upload game film
- See analytics (once you start tagging plays)

## What's Next?

After creating your team, we recommend this order:

### 1. Add Your Roster

Build your roster with player information:

- Navigate to **Players** from your team dashboard
- Click **Add Player**
- Enter jersey numbers, names, and positions
- Having players set up makes it easier to track individual performance

### 2. Invite Coaches

Add assistant coaches to help with film review:

- See [Inviting Coaches](/guide/getting-started/inviting-coaches) for detailed instructions

### 3. Create Your Playbook

Start building your digital playbook:

- Navigate to **Playbook** from your team dashboard
- Click **New Play** to create your first play
- Use the play builder to draw formations and routes

### 4. Upload Game Film

Get your first game into the system:

- Navigate to **Film** from your team dashboard
- Create a new game
- Upload your video file
- See [Uploading Film](/guide/film/uploading-film) for detailed instructions

## Managing Multiple Teams

If you coach multiple teams:

- Each team requires its own subscription
- Switch between teams using the team selector in the navigation
- Each team has its own separate roster, playbook, and film library

## Team Settings

You can update your team settings at any time:

1. Navigate to your team dashboard
2. Click **Settings** in the navigation
3. Update team name, level, or colors
4. Manage subscription and billing

## Tips for Success

> **Start Small:** Upload one game and tag 10-15 plays to learn the system before diving into a full season of film.

> **Add Key Players First:** You don't need your full roster immediately. Start with your starters and add players as needed.

> **Name Games Clearly:** Use a consistent naming format like "vs [Opponent] - Week [#]" to keep your film library organized.

- Check the **Support** section for troubleshooting tips

## Overview

Youth Coach Hub allows you to invite other coaches to collaborate on your team. Each team member can have different access levels based on their role, making it easy to delegate film review and analysis tasks.

## Who Can Invite Coaches?

Only the **team owner** (the person who created the team) can invite new coaches. If you're not the team owner, contact them to request an invitation.

## Available Roles

When inviting a coach, you'll assign them one of these roles:

| Role | Permissions |
|------|-------------|
| **Coach** | Tag plays, view analytics, manage roster, access playbook |
| **Analyst** | Tag plays, view analytics, access playbook (cannot manage roster) |
| **Viewer** | View-only access to film, analytics, and playbook |

## How to Invite a Coach

### Step 1: Open the Console

1. Click on your profile or organization name in the navigation
2. Select **Console** from the dropdown menu
3. This opens your organization management dashboard

### Step 2: Navigate to People

1. In the Console navigation, click **People**
2. You'll see a list of all current team members

### Step 3: Add a New Coach

1. Click the **Add Coach** or **Invite** button
2. Enter the coach's email address
3. Select their role (Coach, Analyst, or Viewer)
4. Click **Send Invitation**

### Step 4: Coach Receives Invitation

The invited coach will receive an email with:

- An invitation to join your team
- A link to create their account (if they're new to Youth Coach Hub)
- Instructions to get started

## What Happens Next?

### For New Users

If the invited coach doesn't have a Youth Coach Hub account:

1. They click the invitation link in their email
2. They create an account using the signup form
3. After verifying their email, they're automatically added to your team

### For Existing Users

If the invited coach already has an account:

1. They click the invitation link
2. They log in to their existing account
3. Your team is added to their team list

## Managing Team Members

### View Team Members

From the Console > People page, you can see:

- All current team members
- Their assigned roles
- Their status (Active, Pending, or Deactivated)
- When they joined the team

### Resend an Invitation

If a coach didn't receive their invitation:

1. Find them in the People list (they'll show as "Pending")
2. Click the **More** menu (three dots)
3. Select **Resend Invitation**

### Change a Coach's Role

To update a team member's permissions:

1. Find them in the People list
2. Click the **More** menu
3. Select **Change Role**
4. Choose the new role

### Remove a Coach

If you need to remove someone from your team:

1. Find them in the People list
2. Click the **More** menu
3. Select **Deactivate**

Deactivated members can no longer access the team but their tagging contributions are preserved.

## Best Practices

### Assign Roles Thoughtfully

- **Coach** role is best for assistant coaches who need full access
- **Analyst** role works well for volunteers who help with film review
- **Viewer** role is useful for parents or players who want to see analytics

### Communicate Expectations

When inviting new coaches, let them know:

- What you expect them to help with (tagging, analytics review, etc.)
- Any naming conventions or tagging standards you use
- How often you'd like them to review film

### Distribute the Workload

With multiple coaches, you can divide film review:

- Assign different games to different coaches
- Have one coach focus on offense, another on defense
- Use the "Tagged by" filter to see each coach's contributions

## Troubleshooting

### Invitation Not Received

If a coach says they didn't receive the invitation:

1. Check that you entered the correct email address
2. Ask them to check their spam/junk folder
3. Resend the invitation from the Console

### Coach Can't Access the Team

If a coach created an account but can't see the team:

1. Verify their status is "Active" in the People list
2. Make sure they're logged in with the correct email
3. Have them refresh their browser or log out and back in

### Reached Coach Limit

Some plans have limits on the number of coaches:

- Check your plan's coach limit in Console > Billing
- Upgrade your plan or purchase additional coach seats if needed

## Next Steps

Once your coaches are set up:

- [Upload game film](/guide/film/uploading-film) for your team to review
- [Learn about tagging plays](/guide/film/tagging-plays) so everyone uses consistent methods
- Review analytics together to improve your game planning

## Overview

Creating plays in Youth Coach Hub allows you to build a comprehensive digital playbook. Each play includes a visual diagram, formation details, and metadata that helps you organize and analyze your offense, defense, and special teams.

## Accessing the Playbook

1. Navigate to your team dashboard
2. Click **Playbook** in the team navigation bar
3. You'll see your existing plays or an empty state if you're just starting

## Creating a New Play

### Step 1: Start a New Play

1. Click the **New Play** button
2. You'll be taken to the Play Builder interface

### Step 2: Choose Play Type

Select the type of play you're creating:

| Type | Description |
|------|-------------|
| **Offense** | Offensive plays with routes, blocking schemes, and assignments |
| **Defense** | Defensive plays with coverage, gaps, and responsibilities |
| **Special Teams** | Kickoff, punt, field goal, and return plays |

### Step 3: Select a Formation

Choose from pre-built formations or create custom alignments:

**Offensive Formations:**
- Shotgun Spread
- Shotgun Trips
- I-Formation
- Singleback
- Pistol
- Wing-T
- And many more...

**Defensive Formations:**
- 4-3 Base
- 3-4 Base
- Nickel
- Dime
- Goal Line
- And more...

### Step 4: Name Your Play

Give your play a clear, descriptive name:

- **Good:** "Shotgun Trips Right - Mesh Concept"
- **Good:** "I-Right 36 Power"
- **Avoid:** "Play 1" or "New Play"

### Step 5: Set Play Attributes

Configure the play's metadata:

| Attribute | Options | Purpose |
|-----------|---------|---------|
| **Play Type** | Run, Pass, RPO | Categorization and analytics |
| **Personnel** | 11, 12, 21, 22, etc. | Personnel grouping |
| **Formation** | Selected formation name | Organization |
| **Concept** | Specific play concept | Film tagging reference |

### Step 6: Build the Diagram

Use the Play Builder to create your visual diagram:

1. Position players on the field
2. Draw routes for receivers and backs
3. Assign blocking responsibilities to linemen
4. Add motion if applicable

See [Play Builder](/guide/playbook/play-builder) for detailed instructions.

### Step 7: Save the Play

1. Review your diagram and attributes
2. Click **Save Play**
3. Your play is added to the playbook

## Play Code System

Each play is assigned a unique play code automatically:

- Format: `P-001`, `P-002`, `P-003`, etc.
- Codes are sequential and unique
- Used for film tagging and analytics

You can also add your own play naming convention in the play name field.

## Play Components

### Diagram Elements

- **Players** - Circles representing each position
- **Routes** - Lines showing receiver paths
- **Blocking** - Arrows showing block assignments
- **Motion** - Dotted lines for pre-snap movement

### Metadata

- **Play Name** - Your naming convention
- **Play Code** - System-generated identifier
- **Formation** - Base formation used
- **Play Type** - Run, pass, or RPO
- **Personnel** - Player grouping (11, 12, etc.)
- **Tags** - Custom tags for organization

## Quick Tips

### Start Simple

When building your first plays:

1. Create 5-10 core run plays
2. Add 5-10 base pass concepts
3. Build from there as needed

### Use Consistent Naming

Develop a naming convention your staff understands:

- Include formation: "Gun Trips..."
- Include direction: "...Left"
- Include concept: "...Inside Zone"

### Add Context

Use the notes field to include:

- Coaching points
- When to call the play
- Key reads for the QB
- Blocking adjustments

### Link to Film

After tagging game film:

- Plays show success rate data
- See when each play works best
- Identify needed adjustments

## Duplicating Plays

To create variations of existing plays:

1. Open the play you want to copy
2. Click **Duplicate**
3. Modify the copy as needed
4. Save with a new name

This is useful for:

- Creating mirrored versions (left/right)
- Adding motion variations
- Building play-action off run plays

## Editing Plays

To modify an existing play:

1. Find the play in your playbook
2. Click to open it
3. Click **Edit**
4. Make your changes
5. Click **Save**

> **Note:** Editing a play updates it everywhere, including film tags that reference it.

## Deleting Plays

To remove a play:

1. Open the play
2. Click **Delete** or **Archive**
3. Confirm the action

> **Warning:** Deleted plays are permanently removed. Consider archiving instead if you might need it later.

## Best Practices

### Organize as You Go

- Tag plays with situations (Red Zone, 3rd Down, etc.)
- Group by formation family
- Mark plays as "installed" vs "future"

### Keep It Current

- Remove plays you no longer run
- Update diagrams after scheme changes
- Archive old plays instead of deleting

### Collaborate with Staff

- Assign coaches to create position-specific plays
- Use consistent terminology
- Review new plays as a staff

## Next Steps

- [Learn the Play Builder](/guide/playbook/play-builder) for detailed diagram creation
- [Organize your playbook](/guide/playbook/organizing-playbook) as it grows
- [Tag plays in film](/guide/film/tagging-plays) to track effectiveness

## Overview

As your playbook grows, organization becomes essential. Youth Coach Hub provides multiple ways to categorize, filter, and find plays quickly during game week preparation and in-game situations.

## Playbook Views

### List View

The default view shows all plays in a list format:

- Play code and name
- Formation
- Play type (run/pass)
- Personnel grouping
- Quick preview thumbnail

### Grid View

A visual grid showing play diagram thumbnails:

- Easier to scan visually
- Good for play selection during games
- Shows key details at a glance

### Formation View

Groups plays by their base formation:

- See all Shotgun plays together
- View I-Formation packages
- Quickly find formation-specific options

## Filtering Plays

Use filters to narrow down your playbook:

### By Play Type

- **Offense** - All offensive plays
- **Defense** - All defensive plays
- **Special Teams** - Kicks, punts, returns

### By Category

- **Run** - Running plays
- **Pass** - Passing plays
- **RPO** - Run-pass options
- **Play Action** - Play-action passes

### By Formation

Filter to specific formations:

- Shotgun
- I-Formation
- Singleback
- Pistol
- And others...

### By Personnel

Filter by personnel grouping:

| Personnel | Meaning |
|-----------|---------|
| **11** | 1 RB, 1 TE, 3 WR |
| **12** | 1 RB, 2 TE, 2 WR |
| **21** | 2 RB, 1 TE, 2 WR |
| **22** | 2 RB, 2 TE, 1 WR |
| **10** | 1 RB, 0 TE, 4 WR |

### By Tags

Filter by custom tags you've created:

- Red Zone
- 3rd & Short
- 2-Minute
- Goal Line
- And your own tags...

## Tagging System

### Adding Tags to Plays

Tags help categorize plays by situation:

1. Open a play
2. Click **Edit**
3. Add tags in the tags field
4. Save the play

### Suggested Tags

Consider tagging plays with:

**Situational Tags:**
- Red Zone
- Goal Line
- 3rd & Short
- 3rd & Long
- 2-Minute
- 4th Down

**Game Plan Tags:**
- Week 1 Install
- Opponent-Specific
- Must-Run
- Constraint Play

**Personnel Tags:**
- Empty
- Heavy
- Spread
- Jumbo

### Using Tags for Game Planning

During game week:

1. Create tags for the upcoming game
2. Filter by those tags during the game
3. Quickly access your game plan plays

## Organizing by Formation Family

### Formation Groups

Group related formations together:

**Shotgun Family:**
- Shotgun Spread
- Shotgun Trips
- Shotgun Empty
- Shotgun Bunch

**Under Center Family:**
- I-Formation
- Split Backs
- Pro Formation
- Ace

### Benefits

- Faster play calling
- Clearer installation plan
- Easier scouting breakdown

## Creating Play Packages

### Concept-Based Packages

Group plays by concept:

**Inside Zone Package:**
- IZ from Shotgun
- IZ from Pistol
- IZ with Motion
- IZ RPO

**Mesh Concept Package:**
- Mesh from Trips
- Mesh from Empty
- Mesh with Wheel
- Mesh with Shot

### Game Plan Packages

Create temporary packages for each game:

1. Tag relevant plays with opponent name
2. Filter by that tag during the game
3. Remove tags after the game or archive

## Search Functionality

### Quick Search

Use the search bar to find plays by:

- Play name
- Play code
- Formation name
- Concept name

### Search Tips

- Search "power" to find all Power plays
- Search "trips" to find all Trips formations
- Search "P-042" to find a specific play code

## Archiving Plays

### When to Archive

Archive plays that are:

- No longer in your active scheme
- Seasonal or opponent-specific
- Experimental plays you're not using

### How to Archive

1. Open the play
2. Click **Archive**
3. The play moves to the archived section

### Viewing Archived Plays

1. Go to Playbook settings
2. Toggle **Show Archived**
3. Archived plays appear grayed out

### Restoring Archived Plays

1. Find the archived play
2. Click **Restore**
3. The play returns to active status

## Playbook Structure Recommendations

### By Level

**Youth/Little League:**
- Keep it simple: 10-15 core plays
- Focus on execution over variety
- Clear naming (Color + Number)

**Middle School:**
- 20-30 plays
- Introduce personnel groupings
- Add situational categories

**High School:**
- 40-60+ plays
- Full personnel/formation variety
- Detailed situational packages

### Organization Strategy

1. **Core Plays** - Your base 10-15 plays
2. **Complements** - Plays that work off your core
3. **Situational** - Red zone, short yardage, etc.
4. **Specials** - Trick plays, rarely used

## Sharing Plays with Staff

### Coach Access

All coaches on your team can:

- View all plays
- Use plays for film tagging
- Filter and search the playbook

Coaches with edit access can:

- Create new plays
- Modify existing plays
- Archive plays

### Playbook Consistency

Benefits of a shared playbook:

- Everyone uses the same terminology
- Film tagging is consistent
- Analytics are meaningful

## Printing and Exporting

### Print Play Cards

Generate printable play cards:

1. Select plays to print
2. Click **Print**
3. Choose format (cards, sheets)
4. Print for wristbands or sideline use

### Export Options

Export your playbook for:

- Backup purposes
- Sharing with other programs
- Printing physical copies

## Best Practices

### Keep It Clean

- Remove plays you don't use
- Update outdated diagrams
- Archive seasonal plays after the year

### Review Regularly

- Weekly: Add new installs
- Monthly: Review organization
- Yearly: Major cleanup and restructure

### Use Analytics

Let performance guide organization:

- Tag high-success plays as favorites
- Archive low-performers
- Build packages around what works

## Next Steps

- [Master the Play Builder](/guide/playbook/play-builder) for better diagrams
- [Tag plays in film](/guide/film/tagging-plays) to see play performance
- [View analytics](/guide/analytics/team-analytics) to identify your best plays

playbook/play-builder.content:
## Overview

The Play Builder is Youth Coach Hub's visual tool for creating play diagrams. It provides a football field canvas where you can position players, draw routes, assign blocking schemes, and add pre-snap motion.

## The Play Builder Interface

### Field Canvas

The main area displays a football field with:

- Yard lines for reference
- Hash marks
- Line of scrimmage (LOS)
- Neutral zone indicator

### Player Icons

Each player appears as a circle on the field:

- **Offense** - Positioned at or behind the LOS
- **Defense** - Positioned in front of the LOS
- Labels show position (QB, RB, WR, etc.)

### Toolbar

Controls for building your play:

- Formation selector
- Play type (offense/defense)
- Route drawing tools
- Motion controls
- Save/cancel buttons

## Positioning Players

### Selecting a Formation

1. Choose a base formation from the dropdown
2. Players automatically position according to the formation
3. Fine-tune positions as needed

### Moving Players

1. Click and drag any player
2. Release to set their new position
3. The diagram updates in real-time

### Position Constraints

- Offensive players must be at or behind the LOS
- 7 players must be on the line of scrimmage
- Maximum 4 players in the backfield

The system validates formations and warns you of illegal alignments.

## Drawing Routes

### For Receivers and Backs

1. Select a player
2. Choose a route type from the assignment dropdown
3. The route appears on the diagram

### Route Types

**Common Pass Routes:**

| Route | Description |
|-------|-------------|
| **Go/Streak** | Straight vertical route |
| **Post** | Vertical then angle to middle |
| **Corner** | Vertical then angle to sideline |
| **Out** | Horizontal break to sideline |
| **In/Dig** | Horizontal break to middle |
| **Slant** | Quick angle to middle |
| **Curl/Comeback** | Vertical then turn back |
| **Flat** | Quick route to flat area |
| **Wheel** | Flat then vertical up sideline |
| **Seam** | Vertical between hash and numbers |

### Custom Routes

For routes not in the preset list:

1. Select the player
2. Choose **Draw Route**
3. Click points on the field to create the path
4. Double-click to finish

### Route Appearance

- **Solid lines** - Primary routes
- **Dashed lines** - Option routes or secondary reads
- **Arrows** - Show direction of movement

## Blocking Assignments

### Offensive Line

For each offensive lineman:

1. Select the player
2. Choose their block type:
   - **Drive Block** - Straight ahead
   - **Down Block** - Block inside
   - **Pull** - Pull and lead
   - **Pass Protection** - Pass set

3. Assign the target:
   - Specific defender (Nose, 3-tech, etc.)
   - Gap responsibility (A-gap, B-gap)
   - Linebacker (Mike, Will, Sam)

### Block Indicators

Blocking assignments appear as:

- Arrows showing block direction
- Labels indicating the assignment
- Color coding for run vs. pass

### Running Backs

For running plays, assign backs to:

- **Lead Block** - Block linebacker
- **Kick Out** - Block end man on LOS
- **Ball Carrier** - The runner
- **Fake** - Run a fake handoff

## Pre-Snap Motion

### Adding Motion

1. Select the player who will motion
2. Choose a motion type:
   - **Jet** - Fast motion across formation
   - **Orbit** - Motion around backfield
   - **Across** - Standard lateral motion
   - **Return** - Motion then reset
   - **Shift** - Formation shift (must set)

3. Set the motion endpoint

### Motion Display

Motion appears as:

- Dotted line showing the path
- Arrow indicating direction
- Different color than routes

### Motion Rules

The system validates motion:

- Only 1 player in motion at snap
- Motion player must be off LOS
- Cannot move toward LOS

## Defensive Plays

### Positioning Defenders

1. Select a defensive formation (4-3, 3-4, etc.)
2. Adjust player positions as needed
3. Assign coverage responsibilities

### Coverage Assignments

For defensive backs and linebackers:

| Assignment | Description |
|------------|-------------|
| **Man** | Cover specific receiver |
| **Zone - Flat** | Cover flat area |
| **Zone - Hook/Curl** | Cover underneath middle |
| **Zone - Deep Third** | Cover deep third |
| **Zone - Deep Half** | Cover deep half |
| **Blitz** | Rush the quarterback |

### Gap Assignments

For defensive linemen and blitzing linebackers:

- **A Gap** - Between center and guard
- **B Gap** - Between guard and tackle
- **C Gap** - Between tackle and end
- **D Gap** - Outside tight end

### Showing Coverage

Coverage zones display as:

- Shaded areas for zone coverage
- Lines connecting man coverage
- Arrows for blitz paths

## Adding a Dummy Formation

### Offense with Dummy Defense

When creating offensive plays, you can add a dummy defense:

1. Toggle **Show Dummy Defense**
2. Select a defensive look
3. Use for teaching coverage reads

### Defense with Dummy Offense

When creating defensive plays, add a dummy offense:

1. Toggle **Show Dummy Offense**
2. Select an offensive formation
3. Shows what you're defending

### Dummy Appearance

Dummy players appear:

- In a different color (lighter/grayed)
- Without route assignments
- For reference only

## Validation Warnings

The Play Builder validates your diagrams:

### Offensive Validation

- **Line count** - Must have 7 on LOS
- **Backfield count** - Maximum 4 players
- **Offsides** - No players beyond LOS
- **Eligible receivers** - End players on line

### Defensive Validation

- **Alignment** - Check neutral zone
- **Coverage assignments** - All DBs assigned

### Warning Display

Warnings appear as:

- Yellow banner with issue description
- Highlights on affected players
- Suggestions for fixes

## Saving Your Play

### Before Saving

1. Review the diagram for accuracy
2. Check validation warnings
3. Add play name and attributes

### Required Fields

- Play name
- Formation (auto-filled)
- Play type (run/pass/etc.)

### Optional Fields

- Personnel grouping
- Tags
- Notes
- Play action indicator

### Save Options

- **Save** - Save and return to playbook
- **Save & New** - Save and start another play
- **Cancel** - Discard changes

## Keyboard Shortcuts

Speed up your workflow:

| Shortcut | Action |
|----------|--------|
| **Esc** | Deselect player |
| **Delete** | Remove selected route |
| **Ctrl+S** | Save play |
| **Ctrl+Z** | Undo last action |

## Tips for Better Diagrams

### Keep It Clean

- Don't overcrowd the field
- Use consistent route depths
- Align players neatly

### Show Key Information

- Highlight primary receiver
- Show the ball carrier path
- Include blocking assignments

### Use Color Effectively

- Primary routes stand out
- Secondary options are subtle
- Blocking is distinct from routes

### Be Consistent

- Use same route types consistently
- Position formations the same way
- Follow your terminology

## Troubleshooting

### Players Won't Move

- Click directly on the player circle
- Drag to desired location
- Release to set position

### Routes Not Appearing

- Make sure player is selected
- Choose a route type
- Check that assignment saved

### Validation Errors

- Read the error message
- Adjust player positions
- Verify formation requirements

### Diagram Looks Wrong

- Reset to base formation
- Rebuild step by step
- Check for overlapping players

## Next Steps

- [Create your first plays](/guide/playbook/creating-plays)
- [Organize your playbook](/guide/playbook/organizing-playbook)
- [Tag plays in game film](/guide/film/tagging-plays)

## Overview

Assistant coaches and other team members can be invited to collaborate on your team with different permission levels. This guide covers the Coach, Analyst, and Viewer roles—everything except the Owner role.

## Role Comparison

| Feature | Coach | Analyst | Viewer |
|---------|-------|---------|--------|
| View playbook | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |
| View film | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |
| View analytics | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |
| View roster | ✓ | ✓ | ✓ |
| Tag plays | ✓ | ✓ | ✗ |
| Create/edit plays | ✓ | ✓ | ✗ |
| Upload film | ✓ | ✗ | ✗ |
| Manage roster | ✓ | ✗ | ✗ |
| Manage schedule | ✓ | ✗ | ✗ |
| Team settings | ✓ | ✗ | ✗ |
| Invite members | ✗ | ✗ | ✗ |
| Billing access | ✗ | ✗ | ✗ |

## Coach Role

### Who Should Be a Coach?

The Coach role is ideal for:

- Assistant coaches
- Offensive/defensive coordinators
- Position coaches
- Graduate assistants
- Trusted volunteers with full responsibilities

### Coach Capabilities

**Full Coaching Access:**

- Create and edit plays in the playbook
- Upload game film
- Tag plays with full detail
- View and analyze team analytics
- Manage the roster (add/edit players)
- Update the schedule (add games, record results)
- Access team settings (view-only for some items)

**Cannot Do:**

- Invite or remove team members
- Access billing or subscription
- Delete the team
- Change other members' roles

### Day-to-Day Workflow

As a Coach, your typical activities include:

1. **Film Review** - Upload and tag game film
2. **Playbook Management** - Create and organize plays
3. **Analytics Review** - Analyze performance data
4. **Roster Updates** - Maintain player information
5. **Schedule Management** - Add games and record results

## Analyst Role

### Who Should Be an Analyst?

The Analyst role is ideal for:

- Volunteer film taggers
- Student managers
- Part-time helpers
- Quality control assistants
- Anyone focused solely on film/playbook

### Analyst Capabilities

**Content Creation Access:**

- View the playbook
- Create and edit plays
- Tag plays in game film
- View all analytics
- Access film library

**Cannot Do:**

- Upload new film
- Manage the roster
- Update the schedule
- Modify team settings
- Invite team members
- Access billing

### Typical Analyst Workflow

1. **Film Tagging** - Tag plays that coaches assign
2. **Playbook Entry** - Digitize plays from paper playbooks
3. **Analytics Review** - Help analyze performance
4. **Quality Control** - Review tagging accuracy

### Why Use Analyst Role?

- **Limited scope** - Focused on specific tasks
- **Safety** - Can't accidentally modify roster or schedule
- **Appropriate access** - Right permissions for the job

## Viewer Role

### Who Should Be a Viewer?

The Viewer role is ideal for:

- Parents wanting to see analytics
- Players reviewing film
- Administrators needing visibility
- Anyone who just needs to watch

### Viewer Capabilities

**Read-Only Access:**

- View the playbook (cannot edit)
- Watch game film (cannot tag)
- See analytics and stats
- View roster and schedule

**Cannot Do:**

- Create or edit anything
- Tag plays
- Upload content
- Modify any data

### Typical Viewer Uses

- Parents checking their player's stats
- Players reviewing game film
- Administrators monitoring the program
- Scouts (with permission) viewing content

## Joining a Team

### Accepting an Invitation

When you're invited to a team:

1. You'll receive an email invitation
2. Click the link in the email
3. Create an account (or log in if you have one)
4. You're automatically added to the team

### Accessing the Team

Once joined:

1. Log in to Youth Coach Hub
2. You'll see the team in your dashboard
3. Click on the team to access it
4. Your permissions are based on your assigned role

### Multiple Teams

You can be a member of multiple teams:

- Different roles on different teams
- Switch between teams in the dashboard
- Each team is separate (different data, subscriptions)

## Working Within Your Role

### Best Practices

**For Coaches:**
- Coordinate with other coaches on playbook organization
- Follow tagging conventions set by the head coach
- Communicate about film uploads to avoid duplicates

**For Analysts:**
- Complete assigned tagging tasks
- Ask questions if unsure about tagging decisions
- Maintain consistency with team standards

**For Viewers:**
- Use the platform for viewing only
- Contact a Coach if you notice issues
- Respect the access you've been given

### Communication

Since you can't change settings or membership:

- Contact the team owner for access issues
- Ask coaches about tagging standards
- Report problems to someone who can address them

## Requesting Different Access

### Need More Permissions?

If you need a different role:

1. Contact the team owner
2. Explain what you need to do
3. They can update your role from the Console

### Role Changes Take Effect Immediately

Once the owner changes your role:

- New permissions are active right away
- No need to log out and back in
- Access updates across all devices

## Common Questions

### Can I see who else is on the team?

Yes, all team members can see the team roster and member list in Team Settings.

### Can I leave a team?

Yes, you can remove yourself from a team through your account settings.

### What if I'm on multiple teams?

You'll see all your teams in your dashboard. Each team is completely separate.

### Can I be an Owner on one team and Coach on another?

Yes, your role is specific to each team. You might own your varsity team and be a coach on the JV team.

### What happens if the owner removes me?

You'll lose access to that team immediately. Your account remains active for other teams.

## Overview

As a team owner, you can invite coaches and staff to collaborate on your team. This guide covers the complete workflow for managing team members—from invitation to removal.

## Accessing Member Management

### Navigate to the Console

1. Click your profile icon in the navigation
2. Select **Console**
3. Click **People** in the Console navigation

### People Dashboard

The People page shows:

- All current team members
- Their assigned roles
- Status (Active, Pending, Deactivated)
- Join date

## Inviting New Members

### Step 1: Start the Invitation

1. Go to **Console > People**
2. Click **Add Coach** or **Invite**

### Step 2: Enter Details

1. Enter the person's email address
2. Select their role:
   - **Coach** - Full coaching access
   - **Analyst** - Film and playbook access
   - **Viewer** - Read-only access

### Step 3: Send the Invitation

1. Review the details
2. Click **Send Invitation**
3. The invitee receives an email

### What the Invitee Receives

The invitation email includes:

- Your team name
- Their assigned role
- A link to accept the invitation
- Instructions for next steps

## Invitation Status

### Pending Invitations

Invitations that haven't been accepted show as "Pending":

- The email was sent
- The person hasn't clicked the link yet
- The invitation is still valid

### Accepted Invitations

Once accepted, the member shows as "Active":

- They can access the team
- Their role permissions are in effect
- They appear in the team member list

## Managing Pending Invitations

### Resending an Invitation

If someone didn't receive or can't find the email:

1. Find them in the People list (status: Pending)
2. Click the **More** menu (three dots)
3. Select **Resend Invitation**
4. A new email is sent

### Canceling an Invitation

To revoke an invitation before it's accepted:

1. Find the pending invitation
2. Click the **More** menu
3. Select **Cancel Invitation**
4. The link becomes invalid

## Changing Member Roles

### When to Change Roles

You might change a role when:

- Promoting an analyst to coach
- Limiting a coach to analyst
- Giving a viewer tagging access
- Adjusting responsibilities

### How to Change a Role

1. Find the member in the People list
2. Click the **More** menu
3. Select **Change Role**
4. Choose the new role
5. Confirm the change

### Role Changes Are Immediate

- New permissions take effect instantly
- No action required by the member
- They'll see their new access right away

## Removing Team Members

### When to Remove Members

Remove members when:

- A coach leaves the program
- Someone no longer needs access
- Cleaning up old accounts
- Security concerns arise

### How to Remove a Member

1. Find the member in the People list
2. Click the **More** menu
3. Select **Deactivate** or **Remove**
4. Confirm the action

### What Happens When Removed

- Immediate loss of access
- Cannot see team content
- Their contributions remain (tagged plays, etc.)
- They can be re-invited later if needed

### Deactivated vs. Deleted

- **Deactivated** - No access, but record preserved
- **Deleted** - Permanently removed (if available)

## Viewing Member Activity

### Team Contributions

See what each member has contributed:

- Plays they created
- Film they tagged
- Games they uploaded

### Tagged By Attribution

When viewing tagged plays:

- See who tagged each play
- Filter plays by tagger
- Useful for quality control

## Best Practices

### Invite Thoughtfully

- Only invite people who need access
- Choose appropriate roles
- Consider privacy of team data

### Regular Cleanup

- Remove departed coaches promptly
- Review member list periodically
- Update roles as responsibilities change

### Communication

When inviting new members:

- Tell them to expect an email
- Explain their role and expectations
- Point them to relevant documentation

### Security Awareness

- Remove access quickly when someone leaves
- Use appropriate roles (don't over-permission)
- Monitor for unusual activity

## Handling Common Situations

### Coach Left Mid-Season

1. Deactivate their access immediately
2. Their tagging work is preserved
3. Reassign their responsibilities

### Volunteer Joining for Film

1. Invite as Analyst role
2. Explain tagging conventions
3. Assign specific games to tag

### Parent Wants to See Stats

1. Invite as Viewer role
2. They can see analytics
3. Cannot modify anything

### New Assistant Coach Starting

1. Invite as Coach role
2. Provide onboarding information
3. Introduce to existing workflows

## Troubleshooting

### Invitation Not Received

1. Check spam/junk folder
2. Verify email address is correct
3. Resend the invitation
4. Try a different email address

### Can't Access After Accepting

1. Verify their status is "Active"
2. Make sure they're logging in with the invited email
3. Have them try logging out and back in
4. Check if the correct team is selected

### Wrong Role Assigned

1. Go to Console > People
2. Change their role
3. Changes take effect immediately

### Need to Re-Invite Someone

1. If they were deactivated, you may need to send a new invitation
2. Use the same or different email
3. They'll go through the acceptance flow again

## Limits and Restrictions

### Coach Limits by Plan

Some plans limit the number of team members:

| Plan | Coach Limit |
|------|-------------|
| Basic | 3 coaches |
| Plus | 10 coaches |
| Premium | Unlimited |

### Reaching the Limit

If you've reached your plan's limit:

- Upgrade your plan for more seats
- Remove inactive members to free up space
- Contact support for options

## Next Steps

- [Understand subscription plans](/guide/subscriptions/tier-comparison)
- [Set up team workflows](/guide/getting-started/inviting-coaches)
- [Review role permissions](/guide/roles-permissions/owner-head-coach)
